item.description: [!WARN] An ongoing note on college, extracting value from an institution whose interests don’t always align with yours. Finding what college is actually good for, and the feeling of agency by shaping your course of study within constraints.
By Nick Seaver “My goal here is to understand how recommender systems make sense to their makers — how they work, who they’re for, why they exist.
By: Janet Abatte Key Ideas: Both an experimental project in packet switching technology + practical resource sharing endeavor with implications of a “survivable” communication network.
The right word. Finding it is thrilling. It’s an unconscious chase we are always on. Even if we don’t realize it.

item.title: 4000 Weeks: Time Management For Mortals
item.description: My tongue-in-cheek one-liner for this book is the anti-productivity anti-self-help productivity self-help book I didn’t know I needed. Oliver Burkeman combines ancient ideas with relatable, 21st-century-specific anxiety-ridden anecdotes into a lucid meditation on our difficult yet truly inescapable relationship with time.

item.title: Beyond From and Content: Beneath Interpretation
item.description: It is only shallow people who do not judge by appearances. The mystery of the world is the visible, not the invisible.

item.title: Find Rhythm. Not Momentum
item.description: Momentum measures how hard it is to stop something once it is in motion. The metaphor of momentum is used (and abused!

item.title: Hacker, Hoaxer, Whistleblower, Spy - The Many Faces of Anonymous
item.description: Coleman traces the origins of the hacker collective Anonymous from “trolls” on Chapter 1: On Trolls, Tricksters, and the Lulz: Definition: “trolling”: the targeting of people and organizations, the desecration of reputation

item.title: Independent Study Writing Grave Yard
item.description: Snippets of writing that I wanted to hold on to: Power users do not necessarily need to be able to “code,” although many might learn if they need.

item.title: Living Book Commentaries
item.description: We’ve all been told and, in turn, tell ourselves to “read more.” I’m skeptical. We also know people who have (claimed to) read everything.

item.title: My Rules for Sanity & Happiness
item.description: I have always had a fraught relationship with rules. So, as a rule, I include in any list of rules the famous Orwellian caveat:

item.title: Non-Violent Communication: A Language of Life
item.description: By: Marshall Rosenberg First Published January 1st, 1999 A Living Book Commentary: Expressing and Receiving Gratitude Example of lousy gratitude: “You are brilliant” - there is no information here.

item.title: Power & Power User
item.description: A Prospectus for an independent study and thesis for my senior year, originating from an incredible seminar on Information—Computing—Infrastructure(History GR8479) taught by Professor Matthew Jones in the Fall of 2022.

item.title: Process Doc. Power User Study
item.description: A growing stack on the notes to self from feedback office hours and all the miscellaneous shit involved in an independent study/thesis, documented here.

item.title: Questions
item.description: What makes some a “mystic”? Walter Benjamin, Simone Weil, philosophers, thinkers, and writers I love who are often labeled as “mystics.

item.title: Style
item.description: Called to emulate - Style - something with the choices the writer maA Argumentative and content –> deliberate choices.

item.title: The Bhagavad-Gita
item.description: Translation: Barbara Stoler-Miller Bhagavad-Gita - Chapter 2, pg 42 As the mountainous depths of the ocean are unmoved when waters rush into it, so the man unmoved when desires enter him attains a peace that eludes the man of many desires

item.title: The Closed World: Computers and the Politics of Discourse in Cold War America
item.description: Book [[Notes]]: On the dissertation book of Paul N. Edwards Preface: “The Closed World emphasizes linkages and problems ignored or downplayed by most extant texts.

item.title: The Inescapability of Gettier Cases
item.description: Ever since Gettier famously highlighted a fault in the concept of knowledge by showing justified, true, belief (JTB) as jointly insufficient for knowledge, there have been many attempts to fix it.

item.title: The Participant
item.description: By: Christopher Kelty Kelty — Ongoing Book Notes: Participation is a “poorly mapped” territory. Often seen as unquestionably ‘good.’ Participation spread.

item.title: The Political Programmer
item.description: A Political Analysis of the Modern Means of Producing Technology based on Walter Benjamin’s Theory of Art and Artist [!

item.title: The Primacy of the Physical in Ibn Tufayl's Philosophical Tale
item.description: What is a human without society? To some, the question is nonsensical; to others, none is more important. Because, for the latter group, the hypothetical isolated human in what later European philosophers call “the state of nature,” shows us how we really are.

item.title: Three Ethical Moments in Debian
item.description: Ongoing notes on Gabriella (Biella) Coleman’s dissertation on the dynamic ethical and motives of Free/Open Source Software (F/OSS) developers through a case study of Debian.
